message_1: Calculate the zeta potential of a colloidal particle, given that the particle has a charge of -3.2 × 10^-19 C, a diameter of 250 nm, and is suspended in a solution with a dielectric constant of 78.3.
message_2:
To calculate the zeta potential of a colloidal particle, we can use the following formula:

Zeta potential (ζ) = (q * η) / (ε * r)

where:
q = charge of the particle (-3.2 × 10^-19 C)
η = viscosity of the solution (we don't have this value, but we can assume it's water at room temperature, which has a viscosity of ~8.9 × 10^-4 Pa·s)
ε = dielectric constant of the solution (78.3) multiplied by the vacuum permittivity constant (8.854 × 10^-12 C²/N·m²)
r = radius of the particle (half of the diameter, so 125 nm or 125 × 10^-9 m)

First, let's calculate ε:
ε = 78.3 * 8.854 × 10^-12 C²/N·m² = 6.93 × 10^-10 C²/N·m²

Now, we can calculate the zeta potential:
ζ = (-3.2 × 10^-19 C * 8.9 × 10^-4 Pa·s) / (6.93 × 10^-10 C²/N·m² * 125 × 10^-9 m)
ζ = (-2.848 × 10^-22 C·Pa·s) / (8.66 × 10^-20 C²/N)

ζ ≈ -32.9 mV

The zeta potential of the colloidal particle is approximately -32.9 mV.
